title: Prasaath Kondreddy vs The Inspector Of Police And Anr on 27 September, 2022
doc:
Prasaath Kondreddy vs The Inspector Of Police And Anr on 27 September, 2022

Author: P.N.Desai

Bench: P.N.Desai

                            1




            IN THE HIGH COURT OF KARNATAKA
                    KALABURAGI BENCH

       DATED THIS THE 27TH DAY OF SEPTEMBER, 2022

                         BEFORE

            THE HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE P.N.DESAI

         WRIT PETITION NO.200970/2022 (GM RES)


BETWEEN:
PRASAATH KONDREDDY
(INDICATED IN CHARGE SHEET
AS PRASANTH KONDA REDDY)
THE THEN PROJECT MANAGER OF
M/S. SRI. AVANTIKA CONTRACTORS (I) LTD,
S/O SHRI. ADISHESHA REDDY,
AGED ABOUT 58 YEARS,
R/AT. SOUTHBAY TERRACE (FLAT-3E) 9,
FIRST MAIN ROAD, GANDHI NAGAR, ADYAR,
CHENNAI-600020

ADDRESS INDICATED IN THE CHARGE SHEET:
R/AT. D.NO.125, KUBERAN NAGAR EXTENSION,
MADIPAKAM, CHENNAI-600 091

                                           ...PETITIONER

(BY SRI. B.V.ACHARYA, SENIOR COUNSEL FOR
ACA JURIS, AMAR CORREA ASSOCIATES
AND AMRESH S. ADVOCATE)



AND:

1.     THE INSPECTOR OF POLICE
       CENTRAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION,
       ANTI-CORRUPTION BRANCH,
       GANGANAGAR,
       BENGALURU 560 032
                                    2




2.      NPTC LIMITED
        NTPC BHAVAN, SCOPE COMPLEX,
        R/AT. NO.7, INSTITUTIONAL AREA
        LODHI ROAD, NEW DELHI 110 003
        REP BY ITS MANAGING DIRECTOR

                                                   ...RESPONDENTS

(BY SRI.MADHAV KASHYAP, ADVOCATE
FOR SRI.PRASANNAKUMAR, SPL.PP FOR R1;
SRI.D.P.AMBEKAR, ADVOCATE FOR R2)


        THIS WRIT PETITION IS FILED UNDER ARTICLES 226 OF
227 THE CONSTITUTION OF INDIA READ WITH SECTION 482 OF
CODE OF CRIMINAL PROCEDURE, 1973, PRAYING TO A) ISSUE
WRIT IN THE NATURE OF CERTIORARI OR OF ANY OTHER NATURE,
QUASHING THE ORDER DATED 20.01.2021 PASSED BY THE SR.
CIVIL    JUDGE    AND      JMFC,   BASAVANA    BAGEWADI,     TAKING
COGNIZANCE AND ISSUING SUMMONS TO THE PETITIONER WHO
IS ARRAYED AS ACCUSED NO. 3, FOR THE OFFENCES PUNISHABLE
UNDER SECTION 120-B R/W 420, 468, 472 AND 511 OF IPC AS
AGAINST THIS PETITIONER, PRODUCED VIDE ANNEXURE - A AND,
B) ISSUE WRIT IN THE NATURE OF CERTIORARI OR OF ANY
OTHER NATURE, QUASHING THE ENTIRE PROCEEDINGS PENDING
IN CC NO. 12/2021 PENDING ON THE FILE OF THE SR. CIVIL
JUDGE     AND    JMFC,     BASAVANA    BAGEWADI,     AGAINST   THIS
PETITIONER      WHO   IS    ACCUSED    NO.3,   FOR   THE   OFFENCES
PUNISHABLE UNDER SECTION 120-B, R/W 420, 468, 472 AND 511
OF IPC, PRODUCED VIDE ANNEXURE - A AND, C) ISSUE A WRIT
OF CERTIORARI OR OF ANY OTHER NATURE, QUASHING THE FIR
IN RC.15(A)/2017 REGISTERED BY THE RESPONDENT CBI AND
CHARGE SHEET PENDING IN CC NO.12/2021 PENDING ON THE
FILE OF THE SR. CIVIL JUDGE AND JMFC, BASAVANA BAGEWADI,
AGAINST THE PETITIONER WHO IS ARRAYED AS ACCUSED NO. 3,
                                3




FOR THE OFFENCES PUNISHABLE UNDER SECTION 120-B R/W
420, 468, 472 AND 511 OF IPC VIDE ANNEXURE - B AND C AND,
D) PASS SUCH OTHER ORDER OR ORDERS AS THIS HONOURABLE
COURT DEEMS FIT IN THE FACTS AND CIRCUMSTANCES OF THIS
CASE.


        THIS PETITION HAVING BEEN HEARD AND RESERVED FOR
ORDERS, COMING ON FOR PRONOUNCEMENT OF ORDER, THIS
DAY, THE COURT MADE THE FOLLOWING:


                            ORDER

This petition is filed by petitioner who is arrayed as accused No.3 in C.C.No.12/2021 pending on the file of Senior Civil Judge & JMFC, Basavana Bagewadi, which arose out of FIR in RC.No.15(A)/2017 seeking to issue writ of certiorari and quash the said proceedings.

2. The brief contention of the petitioner is that the accused No.1 is a Company (M/s Sri.Avantika Contractors (I) Limited,) Represented by its Managing Director along with accused No.2-K.Andrew Vincent/Proprietor and accused No.3- Prasanth Konda Reddy/the then Project Manager of Company (M/s Sri.Avantika Contractors (I) Ltd.) in the project at Kudgi.

4

3. Respondent No.2-National Thermal Power Corporation (hereinafter referred to as 'NTPC' for short) is a public sector engaging business of generation of electricity and allied activities. It awarded the work of Site Levelling and Infrastructure Works of packaging, for its Kudgi Super Thermal Power Project Stage-I (3x800 MW), Karnataka, to accused No.1-Company. On 02.04.2012 the agreement was executed with the work value being Rs.154,34,54,426/- and the period for completion of work was 30 months i.e. starting date as 27.02.2012 and completion date is 26.08.2014.

4. Thereafter, by amendment-I, vide letter dated 18.11.2013, the contract value was increased to Rs.183.54 crores. Then, again by Amendment-II, the contract value was further increased to Rs.189.03 crores, vide letter dated 28.02.2014.

5. It is further contended that due to various reasons, such as, delay in handing over the site by NTPC to accused No.1/Company, free from full encumbrances and obstructions, agitation by land owners, release of construction drawings, etc., again on 09.11.2013, NTPC 5 granted an extension of time for six months upto February 2015.

6. Then, dispute arose between the parties regarding the initial levels and quantities in the RA bills, which led to termination of contract by NTPC on 24.03.2014, which was within the period of contract.

7. As per the contract, Dispute Settlement Clause the several disputes that arose, were referred to the Dispute Resolution Board (DRB). As the decision of said DRB was not acceptable to both the parties, the parties resorted to the Clause i.e. agreed to resolve the dispute through Arbitration, which was a Three Member Arbitration Tribunal.

8. There are claims made by accused No.1 and by NTPC, then relevant issues were framed. The Arbitral Award dated 07.07.2017 came to be passed.

9. It is further contended that during Arbitral proceedings and even before the Dispute Resolution Board, one specific bill, which is Running Account Bill No.15 (RA Bill

15), was the primary issue that was in dispute. Both parties 6 produced detailed evidence before the Tribunal. The Tribunal after discussing in very great detail, both these disputed documents, the signatories to it, the communications in respect of this between both the parties and also the fact of the authorized signatory of the accused No.1/Company by the petitioner herein, who has signed one of the documents along with the representative of NTPC, the Tribunal came to this conclusion:

"Page 101 of Arbitral Award at Ann.D:
"227. Based on the various observations and findings of the Arbitral Tribunal in this regard, the logical conclusion to which the Arbitral tribunal is driven is that the documents Book-
as to Book-16 signed by Mr.Praveen and Mr.Augustine cannot be construed as a proper document for the reasons recorded earlier.....
228. Regarding the documents in Rejoinder Vol.3/1 to 3/10, the Arbitral has already observed that the Vol.3/1 to 3/6 are signed by the authorized representative of the claimant and it is also signed by Mr.Praveen along with other officers of the respondent and the claimant. From this the Arbitral 7 Tribunal finds that the documents in Rejoinder Vol.3/1 to 3/6 can be certainly held to be the documents which are to be relied upon."

Hence, the above Arbitral Tribunal found it just and appropriate to award the balance unpaid specified quantity to accused No.1/Company.

10. The said award was challenged by NTPC before the High Court of Delhi in O.M.P.(COMM).370/2017 and the said petition is partly allowed, upholding the claims awarded in favour of accused No.1/Company with respect to four of the claims and partially another claim. As far as two sets of record of measurements of Original Ground Level data relied by each party and the issue of payment towards RA Bill 15, the High Court held that it was not open for High Court to substitute the said findings, more particularly when as per the settled law. The High Court of Delhi, affirmed the finding of the Tribunal.

11. After the award dated 07.07.2017, the FIR, impugned charge sheet and cognizance order came to be 8 registered on 27.08.2017, which is about two months after the award by the Arbitral Tribunal. The FIR indicates that the Complainant or Informant as mere 'Source Information'. The names of three employees of NTPC is named as accused No.1/M.V.Padma Kumar, Senior Manager (Civil); accused No.2-S.S.Nathan, AGM (Safety) and accused No.3- V.K.Pradhan, General Manager (Project). Accused No.1/Company had been named as accused No.4. After completion of investigation, the charge sheet is filed only against the accused No.1/Company and two other individuals, one among whom is an employee with a private survey enterprise and another who was the then Project Manager, the petitioner herein.

12. It is alleged that there is a criminal conspiracy entered between them and in pursuance of criminal conspiracy, they fabricated second set of Original Ground Level Data and falsified the measurements in the same and further got the signatures of unsuspecting NTPC officials fraudulently on the said fabricated second set of ground level data with an intention to cheat the NTPC.

9

13. It is further alleged that on the basis of said fabricated second set of Original Ground Level Data made a fraudulent claim in the 15 th RA bill by grossly inflating the work done and attempted to cheat NTPC to the tune of Rs.47,15,34,723/- thereby they have committed the offence.

14. In this regard, the charge sheet came to be filed against them before Senior Civil Judge & JMFC, Basavana Bagewadi, Vijayapura District. The learned JMFC has taken cognizance and ordered issue of summons for the offences punishable under Sections 120-B read with Section 420, 468, 472 and 511 of IPC.

15. It is further contended that the proceedings against accused Nos.1 and 2 were quashed by this Court in W.P.Nos.200439/2021 and 200441/2021 dated 23.12.2021. Therefore, the continuation of proceedings against this petitioner/accused No.3 is challenged in this petition.

16. Heard Sri.B.V.Acharya, learned Senior Counsel appearing for Sri.Amar Correa and Sri.Amresh S. learned counsel for petitioner and Sri.Madhav Kashyap, learned counsel appearing for Sri.Prasannakumar Special Public 10 Prosecutor for respondent No.1/CBI, ACB branch, Ganga Nagar, Bangalore and Sri.D.P.Ambekar, learned counsel appearing for NTPC Limited, New Delhi, who is respondent No.2 herein.

17. Learned Senior counsel argued that the allegations made in the charge sheet and materials relied therein, if they are taken at their face value and accepted in their entirety do not prima facie constitute any offence to make out a case against this petitioner.

18. The learned senior counsel further argued that initiation of fresh criminal proceedings and opening it for readmission is not permissible as the same issue was upheld by Delhi High Court, on the findings of Arbitral Tribunal. The FIR was lodged on the basis of 'Source Information' which is not disclosed or revealed. The Investigating Agency cannot sit in judgment of Arbitral Tribunal and findings of the High Court of Delhi.

19. Learned Senior Counsel further argued that one set of Original Ground Level Data has been signed by four officials of NTPC including its Authorized Signatory and it has 11 been signed by the Authorized Signatory of the Company, who is this petitioner and also by another on behalf of the Surveyors as attesting witness. On the contrary the document which is relied as another document has been signed by the Authorised Signatory of NTPC and another person by name Augustine, who is not even the Authorized person to represent the Company. The said Augustine was only a helper to surveying team and he was kind of an only daily wage worker. The said document consists of highly technical and engineering data, it cannot be signed by Augustine, because according to petitioner information even he has not completed his matriculation. The Investigating Agency in their final report, left out the NTPC employees, but only filed a charge sheet against the Company. The learned Senior Counsel further argued that the criminal proceedings are nothing but the proceedings before the Court arising out of contractual dispute.

20. Learned Senior Counsel further argued that after filing of the charge sheet, an appeal was filed in High Court of Delhi in FA(OS) No.91/2020. Learned Senior Counsel further argued that the filing of criminal proceedings is only an after 12 thought and as a counter blast to the award dated 07.07.2017 in favour of the Company and against NTPC, just to put a pressure and with a malafide and ulterior motive a criminal case was registered and the charge sheet has been filed. The charge sheet does not disclose any specific individual who according to CBI has allegedly committed any act of forgery. The FSL report as to whether the document of measurements in question is forged or not is still not forthcoming that itself indicate that the CBI is not definite that as on this day there is no proof of any forgery. It is further argued that the electronic record has been seized from the official of NTPC not by these accused.

21. The learned Senior Counsel further argued that the allegation made in the charge sheet are absurd. There is delay of four and half years in filing the complaint, when the Original Ground Level records, which were alleged to be forged and fabricated and they were available with NTPC since February 2013. None of the ingredients necessary to attract commission of an offence under Sections 120-B read with Section 420, 468, 472 and 511 of IPC are made out. The learned Senior Counsel argued that the matter which is 13 pending is civil in nature, initiation of criminal proceedings is nothing but abuse of process of law and abuse of process of Court.

22. The learned Senior Counsel further argued that as regards allegations of conspiracy, the case against accused Nos.1 and 2 is already quashed and proceedings are terminated, therefore, the said charge is not tenable against this petitioner only. It is also not forthcoming as to whether the specimen signature of accused is obtained to send same to FSL to justify the claim of or to show that RA Bill 15 are fabricated, which are in custody of NTPC only. Therefore, there is no material to show or to substantiate the allegations under Section 468 of IPC. The NTPC employees themselves admitted signatures on the notings maintained in the measurements books, which is appreciated by the Arbitral Tribunal, therefore, the question of fabrication does not arise.

23. The learned Senior Counsel in support of his arguments, has relied on the decision of the Hon'ble Supreme Court in the case of Parbhat Bhai Ahir vs State of Gujarat and Ors. reported in (2017) 9 SCC 641 wherein the 14 Supreme Court held that in a Commercial/Contractual/Civil dispute between the parties no criminal proceeding is maintainable. It is not forthcoming what is the basis for FIR, which is 'Source information'. None of the authorized persons from NTPC which is a Corporation have lodged any complaint. This shows just to put a pressure on respondent, this petitioner and his Company, initiated criminal proceedings. The learned Senior Counsel draw the attention of the Court to the order passed by the co-ordinate Bench of this Court in the above referred writ petition, quashing the proceedings as to how the CBI has exercised its power in a colourable manner.

24. Learned Senior Counsel relied on decision of the Hon'ble Supreme Court in the case of Sardool Singh and Another vs. Smt.Nasib Kaur reported in 1987 (Supp) SCC 146 and in the case of Madhavrao Jiwaji Rao Scindia and another etc vs. Sambhajirao Chandrojirao Angre and others etc., reported in AIR 1988 SC 709.

25. Learned Senior Counsel argued that this petitioner who stands on an identical allegation as that of 15 other accused regarding whom the Co-ordinate Bench of this Court has quashed the proceedings, this petitioner is also entitled for the same relief in view of the material available from the charge sheet. Therefore, learned Senior Counsel argued that the initiation of criminal proceedings, is an after thought. As counter blast to the Arbitral Award dated 07.07.2017 against NTPC which has been held liable to pay an amount of INR 47,54,30,798/- with future interest at the rate of 8.9%, for breach of contract committed by NTPC. The said NTPC colluding with CBI has got filed this case making false allegation just to pressurize the petitioner-Company to come for settlement. Therefore, as the initiation of proceedings is a violation of fundamental constitutional right to life and liberty, the said proceedings are liable to be quashed.

26. Against this, Sri.Madhav Kashyap, learned counsel appearing on behalf of Sri.Prasannakumar, Spl.PP for respondent No.1/CBI argued that as per the order dated 30.05.2017, the Chief Vigilance Commission and on the basis of 'source information' respondent No.1/CBI registered an FIR against four accused persons and after detail investigation, 16 filed the charge sheet. The allegation is that the accused got created a second set of site level records which facilitate accused No.1 to submit inflated false bills to the tune of Rs.47.15 crores. The said documents are fabricated.

27. He further argued that accused No.1 submitted 14 RA bills for the period June 2012 till the termination of contract in September 2013. Each of the said RA bill is accompanied by a covering letter signed by petitioner/ accused No.3 and quantities mentioned therein are duly certified. The bill submitted is approved by General Manger of Kudgi.

28. The learned counsel argued that on bare perusal of RA Bill 15, it is evident that the block wise quantities, which are mentioned in the bill, does not tally with the site diary bearing daily progress for the item No.1 or item No.3 as mentioned in RA.15. So, this shows that RA.15 is a bogus bill submitted just to defraud respondent No.2. The letters were exchanged in this regard and the accused No.1 is not entitled for payment said bill. Accused No.3 who is the petitioner herein and representatives of Accused No.1./Company 17 fraudulently got signatures of the officials of respondent No.2 and same was brought to the notice of accused No.1 and accused No.1 did not come forward to carry the joint measurement of the existing ground level data.

29. He further argued that the investigation reveled that the petitioner and two other accused persons entered into criminal conspiracy and in pursuance to the same have fabricated original ground level data and getting signatures from officials of respondent No.2 fraudulently with an intention to cheat respondent No.2 and submit grossly inflated 15 RA bill. Hence, there has been an attempt to cheat to the tune of Rs.47,15,34,723/-. Therefore, the findings do not come in the way of filing criminal cases. The learned counsel also argued that the criminal proceedings cannot be quashed merely because there is civil proceeding regarding the very same transaction. It is seen whether there is any criminal colour to the civil transactions.

30. Learned counsel further argued that the source of an investigating agency is protected communication and need not be revealed, as held by Hon'ble Apex Court time and 18 again. Therefore, no prejudice is caused to this petitioner by not revealing the source information to this petitioner.

31. Learned counsel further argued that the accused No.1 has not intimated respondent No.2 as to whether said Augustine was authorized representative or not, as his name is found in list of employees of Accused No.1. No argument can be made on that ground.

32. Regarding the submission that as the Arbitration Award is passed as a counter blast, it is argued that respondent No.2 has not filed any official complaint, it is the respondent No.1, based on order of CBI and source information, have took up investigation. Therefore, such ground is not tenable.

33. The learned counsel further argued that the company is an independent legal juristic person. Company is independent of its Directors can be made as an accused. As the source information was received on 27.08.2017 immediately FIR was registered. So, there is no delay on the part of registering the FIR.

19

34. The learned counsel argued that respondent No.1 has challenged the order of this Court quashing the proceedings against accused Nos.1 and 2 before the Apex Court in SLP(Crl) No.007903-007904/2022; and respondent No.2 has filed two separate SLPs, namely, SLP (Crl) No.6402/2022 and SLP (Crl) No.006732/2022 against the order passed by the learned Single Judge in W.P.No.200439/2021 and W.P.No.200441/2021. Therefore, the order of quashing has not attained finality. With these contentions the learned counsel prays to dismiss the petition.

35. Sri.D.P.Ambekar, learned counsel for respondent No.2 argued in the same line that of respondent No.1 and contended that quashing of proceeding in respect of two accused is pending before the Supreme Court and it has not attained finality. There might be negligence on the part of respondent No.2-Company officials in counter signing those documents. But that is not a ground to quash proceedings against this petitioner. Learned counsel argued that in view of the material placed by respondent No.1/CBI, the proceedings cannot be quashed.

20

36. I have perused the FIR, the charge sheet, other materials, the objection statement filed by respondent No.1, decisions relied by the petitioner's counsel and also the judgment passed by the Co-ordinate Bench of this Court against accused Nos.1 and 2.

37. The undisputed contentions are that, on 02.04.2012 there was a contact agreement between M/s Avantika Contractors and National Thermal Power Corporation. Total estimated cost is Rs.189 crore; It is evident that on 24.03.2014 there was a termination of the contract by NTPC. Thereafter, on 23.01.2016 the matter was referred to three Members Panel Arbitration, with claims on both sides, Arbitral Tribunal entered on reference. The dispute was with respect to original ground level data, each party relying on conflicting data sheets. It is not in dispute that on 07.07.2017 Arbitral Tribunal after due enquiry passed the unanimous award awarding Rs.50,21,54,497/- in favour of the petitioner-company and Rs.2,67,23,699/- in favour of NTPC, thus holding the petitioner company being entitled to Rs.47,54,30,798/-. It is also not disputed that on 27.10.2017 about 100 days after the award, and more than 3 ½ years 21 after the dispute started, CBI suo-muto on the basis of 'source information' registered FIR against some officials of NTPC and the petitioner company under Sections 120-B read with Section 420, 468, 471 & 477-A of Indian Penal Code and section 13(2) read with Section 13(1)(d) of Prevention of Corruption Act read with Section 34 of the Indian Penal Code. There was no reference to Arbitral award, whatsoever. It is also not disputed that on 13.10.2017 the NTPC challenged the award before the Delhi High Court under Section 34 of Arbitration and Reconciliation Act. On 08.06.2020, the Delhi High Court confirmed the award passed by the Arbitral Tribunal and dismissed the petition of NTPC. Now the appeal is pending before the Division Bench of the High Court which was filed on 31.07.2020. The CBI filed the charge sheet on 22.12.2020.

38. It is evident from the records that the measurement data sheets relied by the Company was also subject matter of discussion before Arbitral Tribunal. The same was accepted by the Arbitral Tribunal. The main dispute urged before Tribunal is also regarding the measurement regarding original level data as alleged. It is 22 also evident that the data sheet is signed by the authorized person of NTPC and also other authorized representative of the Company. As contended by the petitioner, the said Augustine was not authorized representative of the Company. Therefore, relying on the signature of Augustine, the Investigating Officer have filed the charge sheet against these accused persons.

39. It is evident from records that the dispute is regarding the RA 15 Bill i.e. measurements recorded in original ground level data. The same was subject matter before the Arbitral Tribunal, which was referred by consent of both the parties, the said Arbitral Tribunal after due enquiry passed unanimously award holding that this petitioner- Company is entitled to Rs.47,54,30,798/-. At the cost of repetition I would state that the same was challenged before the Delhi high Court as per Annexure-D dated 07.07.2017; as per annexure-E passed an order uphelding the finding of the Arbitral Tribunal.

40. On perusing the certified copy of charge sheet which is at Annexure-C, it is evident that the three officials of 23 NTPC by name M.A.Padmakumar, S.Shanmuganathan @ S.S.Nathan, and V.K.Pradhan, who were authorized signatories of respondent No.2 have been left out stating that no incriminating evidence found with regard to the above said accused persons for prosecution.

41. I have perused the award at Annexure-D dated 07.07.2017. The arbitrators have raised issues and considered interim application. The issue No.4 is the issue of measurement. The Tribunal at Para No.164 of the award has considered the dispute and held that there is no dispute regarding final levels and also referred clause 37.6 of the contract. When the measurement signed by both the parties on the day of measurement and considered the reference of dispute to DRB and also referred to 7.3 of the Arbitration Act and answered that issue, that the claim No.6 which falls within the jurisdiction and it has also considered the other issues.

42. I have also perused the order passed by the Delhi High Court in OMP (COMM-370/2017). The Delhi High Court dealt with the issues raised in the award and also the 24 compensation and partly allowed the same. Now the appeal is pending.

43. It is evident that after termination of contract in the year 2014, now complaint was lodged and criminal case was registered. On the other hand, on the same dispute and other disputes, the matter was referred to three members of Arbitration. They suffered an award and was challenged and the matter was upheld 08.06.2020 by High Court and now the appeal is pending.

44. The claim was made relating to R.A.Bill.No.15 and also with regard to measurement which was terminated. As per the clause in the agreement the parties went for arbitration. The respondent No.2 did not filed any complaint. On the other hand, the respondent No.1 was set up by respondent No.2. As already stated above, though the FIR was registered against the officials of NTPC, but in the charge sheet they were exonerated stating that there is no evidence against them. Though there is allegation earlier that these persons by colluding with accused Nos.1 to 3 have created the documents and though the authorized signatory of the 25 respondent No.2 have counter signed on those documents but only these petitioners are included. Earlier though Prevention of Corruption Act was invoked, but same not pressed into service. Only contention that there is some allegation against the officials that they have signed on the documents. But against the petitioner and other two the charge sheet was filed alleging that they have fabricated the documents.

45. As discussed above, the charge sheet was filed only when the matter was pending before the Division Bench of High Court against the order of Single Bench of Delhi High Court. It is argued that the Evidence Act is not applicable before Arbitration proceeding. The consideration in departmental proceedings are different from considering the evidence in a criminal case. The same is not disputed. It is also not disputed that the acquittal or conviction criminal case has no bearing on the departmental proceedings, unless the witnesses and the documents and the evidence relied are identical in both the cases. The contention that question of criminal provisions cannot be gone into a arbitration proceeding, has no basis at all in view of the long delay in 26 filing the complaint. Admittedly, the respondent No.1 is a central government employee. When the NTPC officials have counter signed the second set of documents, which is a claim bill in respect of RA.Bill.No.15, there cannot be two standards adopted by the CBI by exonerating them and filing case against petitioner.

46. I have perused the judgment of the Hon'ble Supreme Court in the case of Sardool Singh and Another vs. Nasib Kaur reported in 1987 (Supp) SCC 146, the Hon'ble Supreme Court held that when the matter regarding WILL is seized by the Civil Court, the other side cannot be permitted to institute a criminal proceedings on the allegation that will a forged one. In the decision of the Hon'ble Supreme Court reported in AIR 1988 SC Page 709 in the case of Madhavarao Jiwaji Rao Scindia and another etc., vs. Sambhajirao Chandrojirao Angre and others etc., the Hon'ble Supreme Court held that the alleged breach of trust constituting a civil wrong the criminal proceedings have to be quashed. In that case also the criminal proceedings were instituted for the offence punishable under Sections 406, 467, 27 120-B r/w 34 of IPC. Further at Para No.7, it is held as under:-

"7. The legal position is well settled that when a prosecution at the initial stage is asked to be quashed, the test to be applied by the Court is as to whether the uncontraverted allegations as made prima-facie establish the offence. It is also for the Court to take into consideration any special features which appear in a particular case to consider whether it is expedient and in the interest of justice to permit a prosecution to continue. This is so on the basis that the Court cannot be utilized for any oblique purpose and where in the opinion of the Court chances of an ultimate conviction are bleak and, therefore, no useful purpose is likely to be served by allowing a criminal prosecution to continue, the Court may while taking into consideration the special facts of a case also quash the proceeding even though it may be at a preliminary stage."

47. The Hon'ble Supreme Court in the case of Mitesh Kumar J. Sha vs. State of Karnataka and others, reported in 2021 SC Online 976 and at Para Nos.46 and 47, the Hon'ble Supreme Court held as under:-

28

"46. Recently, this Court in case of Randheer Singh Vs. The State of U.P. & Ors.10 , has again reiterated the long standing principle that criminal proceedings must not be used as instruments of harassment. The court observed as under:- "33. ....There can be no doubt that jurisdiction under Section 482 of the Cr.P.C. should be used sparingly for the purpose of preventing abuse of the process of any court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Whether a complaint 10. Criminal Appeal No. 932 of 2021 (decided on 02.09.2021) 23 WWW.LIVELAW.IN LL 2021 SC 592 discloses criminal offence or not depends on the nature of the allegation and whether the essential ingredients of a criminal offence are present or not has to be judged by the High Court. There can be no doubt that a complaint disclosing civil transactions may also have a criminal texture. The High Court has, however, to see whether the dispute of a civil nature has been given colour of criminal offence. In such a situation, the High Court should not hesitate to quash the criminal proceedings as held by this Court in Paramjeet Batra (supra) extracted above.
47. Moreover, this Court has at innumerable instances expressed its disapproval for 29 imparting criminal color to a civil dispute, made merely to take advantage of a relatively quick relief granted in a criminal case in contrast to a civil dispute. Such an exercise is nothing but an abuse of the process of law which must be discouraged in its entirety."

48. In the light of these principles, if the present petition is considered, and also as the petition against the accused Nos.1 and 2 is quashed by the Co-ordinate Bench of this Court in the above referred writ petitions, the continuation of proceedings against this petitioner is nothing but abuse of process of Court. Nothing is pointed as to how the case of this petitioner is different or differs from the allegation in the charge sheet, from the petitioner and accused No.1 and 2. On the other hand, similar allegations are made against this petitioner and same documentary evidence is relied against this petitioner also. It is also evident that the contract of agreement and documents which are subject matter of criminal case are also the same as that in the arbitration proceedings.

30

49. The contention urged in that petition and the arguments advanced in those writ petitions are one and the same. Therefore, in view of quashing proceedings against accused Nos.1 and 2 in W.P.Nos.200439/2021 and 200441/2021 vide order dated 23.12.2021, in view of the discussion made above and also the principles stated by the Hon'ble Supreme Court in the decisions referred above, in my considered view, the initiation of criminal proceedings against this petitioner also needs to be quashed. Otherwise continuation of proceedings is nothing but abuse of process of law and also it is nothing but the miscarriage of justice.

50. The learned counsel for respondent No.2 has placed the computerized copy of the extract of SLP.(Crl) No.007903-007904/2022; SLP (Crl.)No.6402/2022; SLP. (Crl.) No.006732/2022 and case status report against the order passed by the Co-ordinate Bench of this Court quashing the proceedings. It is not disputed that the matter is not admitted yet and there is no interim stay order passed. The matter is pending for fresh admission. Therefore, there is no stay to the order passed by learned Co-ordinate Bench of this 31 Court in respect of order passed in writ petition filed by accused No.1 and 2.

51. Therefore, in view of the above, in my considered view and in the ends of justice, this petition deserves to be allowed. Accordingly, I pass the following:

ORDER i. The writ petition is allowed.
ii. The order passed by the Senior Civil Judge and JMFC, Basavana Bagewadi in C.C.No.12/2021 dated 20.01.2021 taking cognizance and issuing summons based on the FIR in R.C.No.15(A)/2017 registered by the respondent No.1 - CBI, ACB Bengaluru, for the offences punishable under Section 120-B r/w Sections 420, 468, 472 and 511 of IPC, against the petitioner, is hereby quashed.
Sd/-
